docs.title: Prompt Engineering Course
docs.text:
Welcome to the website for my prompt engineering course. I have been teaching this course since March of 2020. It contains the essential terminology and background for you to become familier with the role of prompt engineering.

When people first start using generative AI they are sometimes both shocked at the quality of the responses and at they same time they become frustrated with their inability to get what they want from models. This cource can help them get the most out of large-langauge models as well as help with image generation.

Please let me know if you find these tools useful.

Good Luck! Dan McCreary on LinkedIn

docs.title: About This Website
docs.text:
I have always been facinated with languge. I got my first exposure to language tools when I discovered WordNet in the late 1990s. It was amazing to see a formal database represnetation of words I used every day. Leveraging WordNet for writing and search was opened a new door for me. This helped me formalize my ability to visualize how to represent concepts in a graph.

I first started using generative AI seriously when OpenAI release their first tools in 2020. I had been using BERT to analize clinical documents, and now there was another model that would not only fill in a single word, but it would continually guess a set of next words.

Back then it was just GPT-2. But it still had potential. I started blogging about GPT-3 in September of 2020 as a way to Generate Detailed Lesson Plans for my STEM students.

Although my peer group of graph and NLP researchers were interested in using these models for task automation, we found that by adding detiled examples of what we wanted we could dramatically increase the quality of prompts. So I started teaching informal one-hour sessions on how to us GPT to perform various tasks that we had formally done by builing custom BERT models.

The more we worked with GPT-3 the more we realized the incredible number of tasks that this single model could do. The demmand for the class continued and I launched both a half-day and eventually a full-day of training for developers. These were often the most popular classes that were offerend by our training group.

Since those early days, the power of generative AI has continued to expand. But the role of writing good prompts is still critical for you to get the most out of your models.

I hope that you find this course useful and I would appreciate any feedback you have to help me make the course better.

Dan McCreary on LinkedIn

docs.title: Contact
docs.text: Dan McCreary on LinkedIn

docs.title: Prompt
docs.text:
Create a glossary of terms for a class on generative AI.
Some terms will have an abbreviation.

Return the results in a single raw markdown file.

For each term use the following format:

#### Term (Abbreviation)

Defintion

docs.title: Adversarial Attack
docs.text: An attempt to deceive a machine learning model through malicious input. This can be done to test the robustness of the model or for malicious intent.

docs.title: Adversarial Training
docs.text: A training methodology where a model is trained to defend against adversarial attacks by including adversarial examples in its training data.

docs.title: Autoencoder (AE)
docs.text: A neural network used for unsupervised learning of efficient encodings by training the network to output its input, generally through a bottleneck layer to produce a compressed representation.

docs.title: Backpropagation (Backprop)
docs.text: A widely used algorithm in training feedforward neural networks for supervised learning. It computes the gradient of the loss function with respect to each weight by the chain rule of calculus.

docs.title: Conditional Generative Adversarial Network (cGAN)
docs.text: A type of GAN that generates data based on certain conditions or labels, allowing more control over the data it produces.

docs.title: COSTAR Framework
docs.text:
An abbreviation for six things to consider when creating a prompt.

  1. Context
  2. Objective
  3. Style
  4. Tone
  5. Audience

  6. Response

  7. How I Won Singapore’s GPT-4 Prompt Engineering Competition

docs.title: Data Augmentation
docs.text: Techniques used to increase the amount of training data by applying various transformations on the existing data, such as rotations, translations, and scaling.

docs.title: Deepfake
docs.text: Hyper-realistic but entirely fake content generated using deep learning techniques. Often refers to videos where a person's likeness is swapped with another's.

docs.title: Discriminator
docs.text: In the context of GANs, it's the component that distinguishes between real and generated samples. Its objective is to classify real samples correctly and to reject generated samples.

docs.title: Encoder
docs.text: The part of an autoencoder that compresses the input into a compact representation.

docs.title: Decoder
docs.text: The part of an autoencoder that reconstructs the input from the compact representation.

docs.title: Few-Shot Learning
docs.text: Description: A machine learning approach where a model is trained to recognize new tasks or categories with very limited data, typically a handful of examples.

docs.title: Generative Adversarial Network (GAN)
docs.text: A class of machine learning frameworks where two networks, the generator and the discriminator, are trained simultaneously through adversarial processes.

docs.title: Generator
docs.text: In the context of GANs, it's the component that tries to generate data. Its objective is to produce data that the discriminator cannot distinguish from real data.

docs.title: Latent Space
docs.text: A compressed, abstract representation of data where similar data points are close together. It's often used in generative models as the space from which they sample to generate new data.

docs.title: Loss Function
docs.text: A function that measures the difference between the predicted output and the actual output. It's used to update model weights during training.

docs.title: Neural Style Transfer
docs.text: A technique in deep learning that applies the style of one image to transform the content of another image, while preserving the content's structure and detail.

docs.title: One-Shot Learning
docs.text: A machine learning paradigm where a model is trained to recognize patterns or make decisions based on only a single example or very few examples of each class or category.

docs.title: Reinforcement Learning (RL)
docs.text: A type of machine learning where an agent learns to behave in an environment by performing certain actions and receiving rewards or penalties in return.

docs.title: Transfer Learning
docs.text: A machine learning method where a model developed for a task is reused as the starting point for a model on a second task.

docs.title: Variational Autoencoder (VAE)
docs.text: A type of autoencoder that aims to learn a probabilistic mapping between the data space and the latent space. It's used for generating new data that's similar to the input data.

docs.title: Zero-Shot Learning
docs.text: A type of machine learning where a model is trained to handle tasks for which it has seen no examples during training.

docs.title: Before the class
docs.text:
1. Make sure students all have access to a generative AI site such as OpenAI ChatGPT.
  2. If ChatGPT is too slow you can also try out Zephyr Chat on Hugging Face.
  3. Remind the students they should all bring laptops to the classroom.
  4. Suggest they bookmark the p5.js Editor site since we will be generating animations and simulations which they will copy to that editor.

docs.title: Classroom checklist
docs.text:
1. Tables with power and enough power strips for each student
  2. Projector and connectors

docs.text:
• OpenAI Prompt Guide
  • OpenAI Prompt Examples
  • Microsoft Promt Engineering
  • Hugging Face Awesome Prompts Dataset
  • Step Back Prompting
  • Let's Verify Step by Step
  • Tipping

docs.title: Initial Prompt
docs.text: Generate an outline of a one hour course on prompt engineering.

docs.title: Final Prompt
docs.text:
Generate an outline of a two hour course on prompt engineering.
Start with an audience and objective.
Assume the audience is business professionals. 
List the key concepts and the order they should be presented.

Response Format:

Return the results in a single raw markdown file that can easily be copied.
Have each part of the class use this header:

"#### Part N: Title (duration in minutes)"

Have each subpart use an unnumbered list.

docs.title: Objective
docs.text: After this course, business professionals should have a solid understanding of prompt engineering, its relevance in the modern business environment, and practical skills to harness the power of advanced language models in their operations.

docs.title: Course Outline: Prompt Engineering for Business Professionals
Introduction (5 minutes)
docs.text:
• Definition: What is prompt engineering?
  • Relevance: Importance of prompts in modern AI and business applications.

docs.title: Part 1: Basics of Prompt Design (10 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Purpose of Prompts:

    • Elicit specific information
    • Drive desired actions
    • Guide AI models

  2. Types of Prompts:

    • Open-ended vs. Closed-ended
    • Leading vs. Neutral
    • Informational vs. Actionable

docs.title: Part 2: Prompt Engineering for AI Models (15 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Principles:
    • Clarity: Avoiding ambiguity
    • Brevity: Keeping it concise
    • Objectivity: Avoiding leading questions
  2. Optimization:
    • Iterative testing
    • Fine-tuning based on feedback
  3. Case Study: Effective prompt engineering in an AI-driven customer service chatbot.

docs.title: Part 3: Business Applications of Prompt Engineering (15 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Customer Engagement:
    • Enhancing surveys and feedback forms
    • Interactive marketing campaigns
  2. Employee Engagement:
    • Tailored training modules
    • Feedback solicitation
  3. Decision Making:
    • Guiding focus groups and brainstorming sessions
    • Elevating quality of business intelligence

docs.title: Part 4: Common Mistakes and Pitfalls (5 minutes)
docs.text:
1. Overcomplication: Avoiding unnecessary complexity
  2. Assumption: Not presuming knowledge or intent
  3. Neglecting Diversity: Importance of considering cultural and linguistic nuances

docs.title: Part 5: Hands-on Activity: Crafting Effective Prompts (5 minutes)
docs.text:
• Participants will be given a generic prompt.
  • They will refine and improve the prompt based on the principles discussed.
  • Discuss and compare different participants' prompts.

docs.title: Part 6: Advanced Techniques in Prompt Engineering (2 minutes)
docs.text:
• Prompt chaining: Using one prompt's output as the input for another.
  • Feedback loops: Continuously improving prompts with iterative feedback.

docs.title: Part 7:  Integrating AI and Prompt Engineering in Business Strategy (2 minutes)
docs.text:
• Enhancing decision-making processes.
  • Streamlining operations and automating repetitive tasks.
  • Enhancing customer experience.

docs.title: Part 8: Conclusion & Q/A Session (1 minute)
docs.text:
• Recap of the key concepts covered.
  • Open the floor for questions and discussion.

docs.title: One-Hour Class for Applied AI
docs.text: Applied-AI-Class.pptx - class taught in November of 2023

docs.title: Generative AI For Teachers
docs.text: ChatGPT-for-Teachers.pptx - class taught in May of 2023

docs.title: List of Labs
docs.text:
1. Lists - Simple list generation - great for test data
  2. License - pick the right license for your GitHub repo
  3. Mermaid - create a diagram or chart
  4. Table - generate synthetic test data in a Markdown tables
  5. Validate - Generate code to validate data like a Zip Code
  6. Generate A Circle - Generate graphic elements
  7. Generate a Bouncing Ball - Generate an animation of a bouncing ball
  8. Generate an Interactive Simulation - Add a slider to the bouncing ball
  9. Explaining Embeddings - Explain embeddings to a 5th-grader
  10. Acceptance Test Plan - Convert an agile story to an acceptance test plan
  11. Job Description - Create the first draft of a job description
  12. Interview Questions - Generate interview questions for a Data Scientist
  13. Multiple Choice Quiz - Generate a multiple choice quiz for a topic
  14. Decomposition - Break a complex problem down into smaller tasks

docs.title: License Prompt
docs.text:
I want to share my traing materials for a class with other teachers.
I would like to allow them to use my lesson plans free.
I would like to ask for attribution.
I don't want them to resell my lessons for profit.

What creative commons license should I choose?

docs.title: Response
docs.text:
For your needs, the most suitable Creative Commons license would be the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial (CC BY-NC) license. Here's why it aligns with your requirements:

  1. Attribution (BY): This license requires others to give appropriate credit for your work, providing a link to the license, and indicating if changes were made. This aligns with your request for attribution.

  2. Non-Commercial (NC): This aspect of the license prohibits others from using the material for commercial purposes. This means that while other teachers can use your lesson plans for free, they cannot sell them for profit, which is in line with your preference.

Under this license, teachers can share, copy, distribute, and transmit the work, as well as adapt it to fit their needs, as long as they attribute the work to you and don't use it for commercial purposes. Remember, though, that the definition of "commercial" can vary, so it's a good idea to be clear in your terms if you have specific concerns or definitions in mind.

}

docs.title: Prompt
docs.text:
Create a Python function that validates a 5 or 9-digit zip code. Allow a dash to be part of the zipcode separating the five and four digits. Provide six sample test cases and run them.

def validate_zip_code(zip_code):
    """
    Validates if the provided zip code is either a 5-digit, a 9-digit number,
    or a 5-digit number followed by a dash and a 4-digit number.

    Args:
    zip_code (str): The zip code to validate.

    Returns:
    bool: True if the zip code is valid, False otherwise.
    """
    if len(zip_code) == 5 and zip_code.isdigit():
        return True
    elif len(zip_code) == 9 and zip_code.isdigit():
        return True
    elif len(zip_code) == 10 and zip_code[:5].isdigit() and zip_code[5] == '-' and zip_code[6:].isdigit():
        return True
    else:
        return False

Test Cases and Results
"12345": Valid (True)
"987654321": Valid (True)
"1234": Invalid (False)
"ABCDE": Invalid (False)
"1234567890": Invalid (False)
"12345-6789": Valid (True)

docs.title: Prompt 1
docs.text: In NLP, what is an Embedding?

docs.title: Response 1
docs.text: In natural language processing (NLP), an embedding refers to a dense vector representation of a word or a textual unit (e.g., sentence, paragraph) in a continuous vector space. The goal of word embeddings is to capture the semantic and syntactic relationships between words, enabling machines to understand and process human language more effectively.

docs.title: Prompt 2
docs.text: Explain Text Embeddings to a 6th-grader

docs.title: Response 2
docs.text:
Hey there! Text embeddings are like secret codes for words and sentences. Imagine you have a special language where every word is represented by a unique set of numbers. These numbers capture the meaning and context of the word.

For example, the word "cat" might be represented by the numbers [0.5, 0.3, 0.8], while "dog" could be represented by [0.7, 0.9, 0.2]. These number codes help a computer understand the words and compare them to find similarities or differences.

Text embeddings are created by teaching a computer using lots of text examples. It learns to find patterns in the words and how they relate to each other. Once it has learned these patterns, it can create these number codes for any word you give it.

The cool thing is that with these text embeddings, you can do all sorts of neat things! You can find words that have similar meanings or even predict what word might come next in a sentence. It helps computers understand and work with words just like we do.

docs.title: Healthcare Costs
docs.text: Asking AI About Lowering Healthcare Costs in the US

docs.title: Prompt
docs.text:
Write a job description for a data scientist.
We use Python for all our data science work.

docs.title: Data Scientist Job Description
docs.text:
Position: Data Scientist

Location: [Your Location]

Type: Full-Time

Department: Data Science

docs.title: About the Role:
docs.text: As a Data Scientist at our company, you will play a pivotal role in leveraging data for strategic decision-making. Your primary focus will be on developing and implementing statistical models and machine learning algorithms to analyze complex data sets. You will collaborate closely with various teams to identify opportunities and challenges within the business, using Python as the main programming language.

docs.title: Key Responsibilities:
docs.text:
1. Data Analysis and Modeling: Utilize Python to conduct robust data analysis, create predictive models, and implement machine learning algorithms.
  2. Data Mining: Identify, collect, and clean data from various sources to prepare it for analysis.
  3. Insights and Reporting: Translate complex data findings into clear, actionable insights for non-technical stakeholders.
  4. Cross-Functional Collaboration: Work closely with other departments to understand their data needs and provide solutions.
  5. Continuous Improvement: Stay abreast of industry trends and advancements in data science and Python programming to continually improve processes and models.
  6. Data Visualization: Create compelling visualizations to communicate findings and results.

docs.title: Qualifications:
docs.text:
• Bachelor’s or Master’s degree in Computer Science, Statistics, Applied Mathematics, or a related field.
  • Proven experience as a Data Scientist or Data Analyst.
  • Proficient in Python and its data science libraries (e.g., Pandas, NumPy, SciPy, Scikit-learn).
  • Strong knowledge of statistical analysis, machine learning algorithms, and data modeling.
  • Excellent problem-solving skills and ability to work in a team environment.
  • Strong communication skills with the ability to present data-driven insights to non-technical stakeholders.

docs.title: Preferred:
docs.text:
• Experience with big data technologies (e.g., Hadoop, Spark).
  • Familiarity with data visualization tools (e.g., Matplotlib, Seaborn, Plotly).
  • Prior experience in a similar industry or business setting.

docs.title: What We Offer:
docs.text:
• A collaborative and innovative work environment.
  • Competitive salary and benefits package.
  • Opportunities for professional growth and development.

docs.title: How to Apply:
docs.text:
Please submit your resume, cover letter, and any relevant work samples/portfolio to [email address/contact information].

Note: This job description can be customized further based on the specific needs and culture of your organization. """

docs.title: Prompts for a Job Interview Question
Prompt
docs.text:
Create a list of interview questions for a data scientist role.
The role uses extensive use of Python data science libraries.
Focus on skills using a knowledge graph.
Ask questions about creating and maintaining a data catalog.
Ask questions about metadata management.
Ask questions about using GitHub.
Ask questions about the Plotly data visualization library.

Return the results as a single raw Markdown file

docs.title: Python Data Science Libraries
docs.text:
1. General Proficiency: Can you describe your experience with Python data science libraries such as Pandas, NumPy, and SciPy? How have you applied these in past projects?
  2. Practical Application: Provide an example of a complex data manipulation task you've accomplished using Pandas.
  3. Problem-Solving: How would you handle large datasets in Python that don't fit into memory?

docs.title: Knowledge Graph Skills
docs.text:
1. Concept Understanding: What is a knowledge graph, and how is it relevant in data science?
  2. Implementation Experience: Describe a project where you implemented a knowledge graph. What challenges did you face and how did you overcome them?
  3. Tools and Technologies: What tools or libraries have you used for building or interacting with knowledge graphs in Python?

docs.title: Data Catalog Creation and Maintenance
docs.text:
1. Fundamentals: Can you explain what a data catalog is and its importance in data management?
  2. Experience: Describe your experience in creating and maintaining a data catalog. What tools or platforms did you use?
  3. Best Practices: What are some best practices for ensuring the accuracy and reliability of a data catalog?

docs.title: Metadata Management
docs.text:
1. Understanding Metadata: How do you define metadata in the context of data science, and why is it important?
  2. Practical Application: Can you describe a scenario where metadata management was crucial in your project? How did you handle it?
  3. Challenges: What are the most common challenges in metadata management, and how do you address them?

docs.title: GitHub Usage
docs.text:
1. Basic Usage: How do you use GitHub for version control in your data science projects?
  2. Collaboration: Can you discuss a time when you used GitHub for collaborative development on a data science project?
  3. Advanced Features: Are you familiar with advanced GitHub features like actions, projects, or workflows? Can you provide examples of how you've used them?

docs.title: Plotly Data Visualization Library
docs.text:
1. Library Proficiency: How have you used Plotly in your past data science projects? Provide specific examples.
  2. Comparative Analysis: How does Plotly compare to other visualization tools or libraries you have used?
  3. Advanced Visualization: Describe the most complex visualization you have created using Plotly. What were the challenges and how did you resolve them?

docs.title: Multiple Choice Quiz
docs.text:
Generate a Markdown formatted multiple-choice quiz for an interview 
with a data science candidate.
The data science candidate should know Python
and machine learning libraries.
They should be familiar with generative AI
and LangChain.
Generate 10 questions, each with four
possible answers.
Only one answer will be correct.
Place the string "[CORRECT]" after each correct answer.
Use header level 4 for the question text.
Use a list with labels A. B. C. D. for the options.

docs.title: Sample Response
docs.text: Certainly! Here's a Markdown-formatted multiple-choice quiz tailored for interviewing a data science candidate who is knowledgeable in Python, machine learning libraries, generative AI, and LangChain.

docs.title: 1. What is the primary library used for scientific computing in Python?
docs.text: A. TensorFlow B. PyTorch C. Numpy D. Pandas E. Numpy [CORRECT]**

docs.title: 2. Which of the following is not a supervised learning algorithm?
docs.text: A. Decision Trees B. K-Means Clustering [CORRECT] C. Linear Regression D. Support Vector Machines

docs.title: 3. In Pandas, how do you select the rows where the column 'age' is greater than 25?
docs.text: A. df[df['age'] > 25] [CORRECT] B. df.select('age' > 25) C. df.where('age', '>', 25) D. df.query('age' > 25)

docs.title: 4. What is the main advantage of using PyTorch over TensorFlow for certain applications?
docs.text: A. Better community support B. Dynamic computation graph [CORRECT] C. More deployment options D. Superior performance on CPUs

docs.title: 5. Which Python library is primarily used for advanced machine learning model development, particularly for deep learning?
docs.text: A. Scikit-learn B. Numpy C. TensorFlow [CORRECT] D. Matplotlib

docs.title: 6. When training a machine learning model, what is the purpose of splitting the dataset into training and testing sets?
docs.text: A. To speed up the training process B. To prevent overfitting by validating the model on unseen data [CORRECT] C. To increase the size of the dataset through bootstrapping D. To ensure that the model only works with clean data

docs.title: 7. What is Generative AI primarily concerned with?
docs.text: A. Classifying images into predefined categories B. Predicting numerical values based on historical data C. Generating new content or data based on learned patterns [CORRECT] D. Enhancing the resolution of images

docs.title: 8. In the context of deep learning, what does the term "backpropagation" refer to?
docs.text: A. The process of updating the weights of a neural network backward, from output to input [CORRECT] B. Propagating input data forward through the network to generate an output C. The method of calculating the gradient of the network's output against its input D. A technique for visualizing the activation of neurons in early layers

docs.title: 9. LangChain is a framework designed for what purpose?
docs.text: A. Web development B. Building and deploying generative AI applications [CORRECT] C. Data visualization D. Statistical analysis

docs.title: 10. What is the primary benefit of using ensemble learning methods like Random Forests in machine learning?
docs.text:
A. They are easier to interpret than deep learning models B. They require less computational power than SVMs C. They can significantly improve prediction accuracy by combining multiple models [CORRECT] D. They are unaffected by missing data

This quiz covers a broad range of topics in Python, machine learning libraries, generative AI, and LangChain, making it a suitable test for a data science candidate's expertise in these areas.

docs.title: GitHub Repository Analyzer
docs.text:
This demo uses the AskTheCode plugin. This tool samples files within a GitHub repository to find out what the repository does.

Analyze the code in the following GitHub repo:

https://github.com/dmccreary/prompt-class

docs.title: Response
docs.text:
The repository "prompt-class" by dmccreary contains a variety of files, including Markdown documents, PowerPoint slides, CSV data files, and images. The repository seems to be structured primarily for educational or instructional purposes, focusing on topics related to AI and data analysis. Here's a breakdown of the contents:

Markdown Documents (*.md): These files are likely used for documentation or instructional content. They include topics like an about page, contact information, a glossary, instructor notes, and a sample outline. There are also lab exercises covering various topics such as Markdown tables, Mermaid diagrams, and data analysis.

PowerPoint Slides (*.pptx): There are PowerPoint presentations, possibly used for lectures or presentations in a classroom or workshop setting.

CSV Data Files (*.csv): The data files, such as healthcare-costs.csv and life-expectancy.csv, are likely used for data analysis exercises or examples in the course material.

Images (*.png): Images like blue-circle.png, mermaid-workflow.png, and table.png are probably used within the documentation or slides to illustrate concepts or provide examples.

Configuration and Miscellaneous Files: Files like mkdocs.yml and .DS_Store are configuration or system files. The mkdocs.yml suggests that the documentation might be built into a static site, possibly for easy access and navigation.

Static Site Files: There are files and directories that indicate the presence of a static site (site/ directory), including HTML files, JavaScript, CSS, and a search index. This further supports the use of MkDocs or a similar static site generator for documentation.

Workspace File: The prompt-class.code-workspace file is a workspace configuration file, likely for Visual Studio Code, indicating that this project may be set up for use in that IDE.

This repository seems to be a comprehensive resource for teaching or learning about AI, data analysis, and related technologies, with a mix of theoretical and practical content. The lab exercises and data files suggest hands-on learning components.

For more detailed analysis or specific questions about the code or content, I can look into individual files.

docs.title: Course Description
docs.text: This course is designed to teach students how to create effective prompts for large language models (LLMs) like GPT-3. The course covers a range of topics, including the basics of LLMs, understanding prompt engineering, and advanced techniques for prompt optimization.

docs.title: Course Objectives
docs.text:
• Understand the fundamentals of large language models.
  • Learn the principles of prompt engineering.
  • Develop skills to optimize prompts for specific tasks.

docs.title: Course Structure
docs.text: The course is divided into several modules, each focusing on different aspects of prompt engineering. Labs and hands-on exercises are included to provide practical experience.

docs.title: Instructor
docs.text: Dan McCreary is the instructor for this course. He has extensive experience in AI and data management.

docs.title: Contact Information
docs.text: For more information, please refer to the Contact page.

docs.title: License
docs.text: This course material is licensed under the Creative Commens

docs.title: Prompt
docs.text:
Create a Python plotly program to draw a vertical bar chart.
Show the area of all the continents.
Verify the code is correct.

import plotly.express as px

# Example data, in reality, this should be replaced with the actual data.
# The values here are rough estimates and not accurate.
continents = ['Asia', 'Africa', 'North America', 'South America', 'Antarctica', 'Europe', 'Australia']
area = [44579000, 30370000, 24709000, 17840000, 14000000, 10180000, 8600000] # in square kilometers

# Create a vertical bar chart
fig = px.bar(x=continents, y=area, title="Area of Continents", labels={'x':'Continent', 'y':'Area (sq km)'})

# Show figure
fig.show()

docs.title: Debugging Tip
docs.text:
I originally called the file plotly.py

I asked ChatGPT:

import plotly.express as px

ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'plotly.express'; 'plotly' is not a package

When I ask "pip freeze", it says the following libraries are installed:

plotly @ file:///opt/conda/envs/env/conda-bld/plotly_1698259245963/work/packages/python/plotly/dist/plotly-5.18.0.tar.gz
plotly-express==0.4.0

The error you're encountering, ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'plotly.express'; 'plotly' is not a package, suggests a conflict or issue with your Plotly installation. Here are some steps to resolve this issue:

Check for Name Conflicts: Ensure there are no files or directories in your working directory named plotly.py or a folder named plotly. Such conflicts can cause Python to try to import your local file or directory instead of the actual Plotly package.

docs.title: Acceptance Test Plan
docs.text:
Using Agile development, a product manager typically writes "Stories" about how the users interact with a system. These Stories are then converted to an Acceptance Test Plan (ATP) by the developer using a formal grammar called "Cucumber Format".

Generative AI is VERY good at writing ATPs! A well-written ATP typically saves an organization $50 and even more if the developers are non-native English speakers.

docs.title: Sample Prompt
docs.text:
We are creating a new website to allow people to
register for demos with their email.  Please write
an acceptence test plan for the registration form
using cucumber format.

docs.title: Sample Response
docs.text: Creating an Acceptance Test Plan (ATP) in the Cucumber format involves writing scenarios in Given-When-Then steps, which describe both the setup, the action, and the expected outcome for each feature being tested. Here's an ATP for registering new users on your site, which will include tests for both successful registrations and handling of common errors.

docs.title: Scenario: Successfully register a new user
docs.text:
• Given the user is on the registration page
  • When the user enters a valid username, email, and password
  • And submits the registration form
  • Then the user receives a confirmation email
  • And the user is redirected to the welcome page

docs.title: Scenario: Registration with an already taken username
docs.text:
• Given the user is on the registration page
  • When the user enters a username that is already taken
  • And fills in the rest of the form correctly
  • And submits the registration form
  • Then the user sees an error message indicating the username is already taken

docs.title: Scenario: Registration with an invalid email address
docs.text:
• Given the user is on the registration page
  • When the user enters an invalid email address
  • And fills in the rest of the form correctly
  • And submits the registration form
  • Then the user sees an error message indicating the email is invalid

docs.title: Scenario: Registration with a weak password
docs.text:
• Given the user is on the registration page
  • When the user enters a password that is too weak
  • And fills in the rest of the form correctly
  • And submits the registration form
  • Then the user sees an error message indicating the password is too weak

docs.title: Scenario: Registration form submitted with missing fields
docs.text:
• Given the user is on the registration page
  • When the user submits the registration form with one or more fields missing
  • Then the user sees error messages indicating which fields are required

docs.title: Additional Tips for Effective ATPs
docs.text:
• Clarity and Detail: Ensure that each step is clear and detailed enough so that anyone in the team can understand what needs to be done and what is expected without requiring additional explanation.
  • Edge Cases: Consider adding scenarios for edge cases, such as attempting to register with special characters in the username, or input fields exceeding maximum length.
  • Security and Compliance: Include scenarios that ensure data is being handled securely and in compliance with relevant regulations, such as GDPR for users in the European Union.
  • Performance: Consider scenarios that test how the registration process behaves under high load, though this might be more relevant for Load Testing rather than functional acceptance testing.

This ATP framework is designed to cover basic functionalities and common error handling in the user registration process, providing a solid foundation for ensuring a smooth user experience.

docs.title: Decomposition
docs.text: Generative AI is VERY good at helping you break large projects down into smaller projects. Here is an example of using Generative AI to decompose a large project into small tasks.

docs.title: Prompt
docs.text:
I want to create a web form that gathers information
to build an AI strategy for a company and then 
uses generative AI to sugget
some microstrategies to help them improve their innternal
capabilities with AI.

Suggest how I can break this problem down into smaller parts
so I can build this tool step-by-step.

docs.title: Sample Response
docs.text: Building a web form and tool that leverages generative AI to suggest microstrategies for enhancing a company's internal AI capabilities is a multifaceted project. Here's a breakdown into smaller, manageable parts to help you develop this tool step by step:

docs.title: 1. Requirements Gathering and Planning
docs.text:
• Define the Scope: Clearly outline what the AI strategy tool will cover. This includes the types of companies it's aimed at (size, industry, current AI maturity level), and the range of AI capabilities it will suggest improving (e.g., data management, model development, deployment).
  • Identify User Inputs: Determine what information you need from the companies. This could include their current AI projects, tools, team skills, data infrastructure, and specific goals or challenges.
  • Research AI Strategy Elements: Understand the components of an AI strategy to ensure your tool provides comprehensive and relevant suggestions. This includes staying updated with AI trends and industry best practices.

docs.title: 2. Designing the Web Form
docs.text:
• Select a Technology Stack: Choose the technologies for frontend and backend development (e.g., React for the frontend, Node.js for the backend).
  • Web Form Design: Design the form to be user-friendly and intuitive, ensuring it collects all necessary information efficiently without overwhelming the user.
  • Validation and Security: Implement input validation to ensure data integrity and security measures to protect sensitive information.

docs.title: 3. Developing the AI Model
docs.text:
• Select Generative AI Tools: Decide on the generative AI models to use. This could involve using existing models like GPT (from OpenAI) for generating text-based strategies.
  • Training/Customization: If customization is needed, prepare a dataset for training or fine-tuning the AI models on strategy suggestions. This could involve gathering existing AI strategies and outcomes.
  • Integration: Develop the integration layer that connects your web form inputs with the AI model, ensuring the model can generate suggestions based on the input data.

docs.title: 4. Generating AI Strategy Suggestions
docs.text:
• Implement Logic for Suggestions: Build the logic that takes user inputs and translates them into prompts for the AI model. This involves creating a mapping between the company's current state (as described by the form inputs) and the types of suggestions that would be most useful.
  • Customization and Refinement: Allow for customization of suggestions based on the specific needs and context of the company, possibly including an iteration or feedback mechanism for users to refine suggestions.

docs.title: 5. User Interface and Experience
docs.text:
• Displaying Suggestions: Design how the AI-generated strategies will be presented to the user. This could include categorizing suggestions, prioritizing them, or providing additional resources for implementation.
  • Feedback Mechanism: Implement a way for users to provide feedback on the usefulness of the suggestions, which can be used to improve the model and logic over time.

docs.title: 6. Testing and Iteration
docs.text:
• Pilot Testing: Before full deployment, test the tool with a small group of companies to gather feedback and identify any issues.
  • Iterate Based on Feedback: Use the feedback to refine the web form, the AI model's integration, and the presentation of the suggestions.

docs.title: 7. Launch and Continuous Improvement
docs.text:
• Deployment: Deploy the tool for wider use, ensuring it is hosted on a scalable and secure platform.
  • Monitor and Update: Continuously monitor the tool's performance, user feedback, and the evolution of AI strategies to update your suggestions and ensure relevance.

docs.title: 8. Documentation and Support
docs.text:
• User Guide: Create documentation to help users understand how to use the tool and interpret its suggestions.
  • Technical Support: Set up a support system for users to report issues or seek help with the tool.

Breaking down the project into these manageable steps allows you to focus on one aspect at a time, making the development process more structured and manageable. It also helps in ensuring that each component is thoroughly developed, tested, and optimized for the best possible user experience and effectiveness.
